content.description:
This line was climbed by Todd Kabaluk in 1997. Start the same as Dont Panic and head into the crack shared with Snakes and Ladders. Where the Snakes and Ladders crack heads right, leave the crack and take the unprotected slab to the top. Bold to say the least. A good mental test piece. Don't clip any bolts! Gear only!!

single rack.

Climb the bottom of End of the World and follow the left hand seam at the ledge. Thin finger pods change to a rooty crack to the anchor.



The last climb, furthest right on the E wall.

Single rack + bolts,

Super fun line. 7 bolts. The hard stuff is at the first bolt. Balancey smears, pockets and slopers, unique climb.


7 bolts, bolted anchor

Fun friction climbing broken up by ledges.



6 bolts

Climb thin edges to an anchor under a short roof.



Far East walls past the new footbridge

Bolts

An amazing line that climbs edges and shallow pockets just to the right of the exposed arete. Grab the first tree to exit for now until we clean the ledge above. 
  
 Immediately to the right of this climb is 16 Tonnes, 5.7 or 5.8. Slab climbing to a thin crack then more slab climbing.

On the east trail where the trail begins to climb to the main wall. The large slab will have 3 to 4 more lines that will lead into 1 or 2 more pitches above.
8 bolts with 2 draws at the anchors. We will be adding chains in the near future. Please leave the draws.

climbs.name: The End of the World as We Know it

content.description:
A 5.8ish crack leads to a ledge. Follow the right hand seam to the top through amazing finger pods and edges on bolts.



The last route on the East Wall

Single rack and bolts

P1 Trad, 5.9, up the obvious corner to the tree
P2 Sport, 5.10, leave the belay to the right out from under the roof and clip bolts up the face to the next tree
P3 Mixed, 5.9+, climb a bolt ladder to the base of a great crack that widens fingers to fists.Â 

For an excellent adventure link all 3 pitches in one 69m long mega pitch!!!



Far East Wall, up an obvious left facing corner.

Single rack to #4, 2x #3's

A unfinished 90s line by Todd that can now finish at the Not so Tirf anchor. 4 bolts. Could probably use a bit more scrubbing.



Line directly left of Not so Tirf. Last bolt line before the small cave/roof.

4 bolts

climbs.name: Girls from Tulameen roll their joints all wrong

content.description:
Climb a ramp into thin edges up to an anchor left of a tree, below a short roof.



Far East walls, over the bridge past the foot bridge

Bolts

Another great friction climb broken up by small ledges. Very easy up top. Join into the last couple bolts of Safety Dance or head left to the middle anchor.



Bolts.

A fun trad line. Clip the arguably low first bolt and start plugging gear from there. Hard to tell from looking up but there is ample opportunity for solid pro in several horizontal cracks. Rack from .3-2. Doubles in .4-.75 could be useful as well as a #4 if your uncomfortable reaching the horizontal crack after the first ledge. Great line.Â 



East wall.

1 bolt. Single rack .3-2. optional doubles in .4-.75.

Bolts up the face on thin edges reminiscent of skaha. To the right of the obvious corner, can be linked into the 2nd pitch of Firefox.


Bolts

A significant ledge traverse leading into a stunning chimney. A one of a kind for Harrison! Ledge is very straight forward with few hand holds, scurry up the base of the tree and into the chimney and begin the fun part! Tree anchor chain ontop. Belay your second climber from above and rap down together or lower back to belay station. 70m rope does the trick dedicated to Jane Bleakney 1935-2021 Approach from top of "rumble in the jungle" or "name of the wind" or the handline trail right of the slab. Walk up to the wall itself and walk left below the chimney along an easy ledge to the handline which takes you directly to the belayers anchor. Bolts, anchors top and bottom

Hard climbing past the first bolt and at the last bolt if you go right. 4 bolts and some gear for the top. Shares the anchor with Moon Boots.


4 bolts. Gear up top.

Identifiable by the large pocket in the middle. From the ramp climb past 4 bolts. Â Bring a couple peices of gear for the top or run it out on easy 5.5.


bolts. optional gear.

20m sloping traverse starting at the ground along the obvious gash right of "moon boots" and crossing "unnamed crack". Ends at "baby pitch" middle anchor. Crux is the last move which is best protected by an alpine draw on the baby pitch bolt


Mixed with bolted anchor

Easy crack with several ledges. Single rack should do it. Can climb the beginning of this crack and exit left at the ledge for easy access to Rumble in the Jungle.


single rack. anchor with rap rings

Sport line to the left of Crimp Shocktail. Crux comes in the first 4 bolts with easier climbing above. An Old 90s bolt line shared the first 3 bolts but stepped left at the first shelf past a lone bolt, carrying on with gear. Fun crimping.Â 



East wall.

Bolted anchor. 6 draws. optional gear.

Second pitch above the slab. Can be climbed from either anchor or as one long pitch linking a lower route. 70m works. Fun relaxed climbing with a bolt protected crux. Makes for a good beginner trad lead. Single rack from .3-2. 3 bolts.Â 

A similar line was climbed by Todd in the 90s, named Windy. Unsure of the exact line.


Single rack. 3 bolts

4 bolts and a single rack. .3-2 BD. Mixes the good part of the trad climbing with some excellent crimps. The 5.10 climbing is through the bolts.Â 



East Wall

4 bolts. bolted anchor. single rack. .3-2 BD

Climb the easy crack/up the ramp to the small roof. Pop a piece or two under the roof and pull into the sweet layback. Solid pro. Solid fingers. Bring doubles in .2/.3 and a single .4 for the layback plus a cam or two for the easy crack.

Second pitch/extension. 5 bolts. From the first anchor clip an extended draw and traverse right clipping one bolt on the good fingers to the ledge. Continue up the technical face to the big ledge with an anchor. A worthy but challenging addition to the route. Do it as full pitch 35m. 11c/d



East wall

single rack, double in .2, .3.

Right leaning crack fingers to hands to an anchor under a tree.



Belay from just above a foot bridge past the beginner slab

Single rack

Super fun route. Couple cams (.3, .4) and 4 bolts. Reachy moves, Beware 5' 5" and shorter.


Bolted anchor. 4 bolts and a few cams.

Fingery edges ascend through a couple horizontal seams to an anchor right of a tree with a chain on it.


Bolts

The second pitch from the Poor Choices and Under Pressure anchor. Can also be easily accessed by climbing Moon Boots crack and heading left to the anchor at the ledge.

Â Lay back until you can get into the crack. Follow the cracks and ledges to the top. crux comes about 2/3 way up. Stay on the right crack. Single rack from .3-2 BD cams (bring your nuts). Some may want doubles in .4, .5, .75 cams. Small nuts and .1, .2 BD cams are nice for the top but not necessary. 2 bolts where the gear runs dry.

75m rope! tie your knots. Can be done with a 60m if you rap to the Don't Panic its Organic anchor to the right.



Start at the Poor choices anchor.

.1-2 BD, doubles in  .4, .5, .75

climbs.name: Safety Dance
climbs.fa: FA J. Fast, route by J. Fast and S. Bleakney, Apr 2021

content.description:
Best beginner lead on the wall. Furthest route on the right. Can stay on the slab for the proper route or climb the ramp just left and still clip the bolts. Bit of friction slab with big crimps thrown in. Excellent climbing.Â 


7 bolts. Anchor with rap rings

9 bolts to the top. Crux is down low, easier climbing above. Good varied climbing. Anchor with rap rings.



To the left of Unnamed Crack. East wall.


9 bolts.

The obvious crack that zig zags across the wall. Make your way left up the ramp, step into the finger crack (can optionally clip Dont Panic bolt) and then continue right to the anchor. A single rack from .3-3 is enough. Easy fun climbing, makes a great beginner trad lead. Bolted anchor with rap rings.


Single rack.

P1. 11b/c. Climb good crimps and ledges to a thin technical crux near the top. End on the belay ledge. 12 bolts, 32m. Sport. **Can climb Pull My Finger alternately for the first pitch at 11a.

P2. 10b. A short traverse pitch trending right and up. Finishes on the large ledge. 5 bolts. Sport.

P3. 10b. From the large ledge head into the excellent right trending finger crack. Great finger jams with feet on the face. Super fun, solid pro. Finish up the arete clipping one bolt. A few cams from .2-.4 and nuts. Trad.

Linking the last 2 pitches or all the pitches is possible. Watch for rope drag if linking the second two. Can be climbed and rapped with a single 60m.



East wall

12 draws, nuts and a couple finger sized cams.

Small pockets, ledges and tricky smearing. Shares the anchor and last bolt with Poor Choices. Fun Climbing. 6 bolts.



At the east wall, between poor choices and Moon Boots crack.

6 bolts. anchor with rap rings.

climbs.name: Unnamed Crack
climbs.fa: John Valecko 2019. Cleaned 2018 by Joe McKeen

content.description:
A straight in, fun and straightforward hand to fist crack with a couple of pods that runs up the steeper wall left of the Don't Panic It's Organic/Sixteen Tonnes slab to the DPIO anchor.

Joe cleaned most of it and then got distracted by other stuff. John got the send.

Left of Don't Panic Its Organic, around the arete. Follow East Wall trail past Kingergarten Corner, climb over short scrambly boulder, continue past Cooks Crack and Skinny Fingers to flat area with lots of cedars, set back to the slough a little bit from the crag. Walk short trail in to the base. The left side of the East Wall. Â 

Gear to 3". Rap from anchor at top of the crack or move around the arete and continue up Don't Panic to that route's anchor.

Three-four pitch high, east facing wall that holds long climbs on edgier rock than the rest of the Harrison Bluffs. Bring strong fingers for crimping. The cut off from East Wall Trail to East Wall is the Arete just right of Given'er the Beans.

Area is currently in Development. Wear Helmets and respect any ropes hanging.
